name: Canyon Creek Services
description:
Domestic Violence Women's Shelter
We also have an Outreach Center where our main offices are outside of the shelter for those that do not need shelter but may need legal assistance or resources.

The mission of the Canyon Creek Women's Crisis Center (CCWCC) is to provide free, confidential help for survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault, and victims of crime. We provide 24 hour crisis intervention, emergency services to assist survivors in escaping abuse, breaking the cycle of violence, and supporting them through their healing journey. We also collaborate with the community in an effort to end domestic violence and provide preventative education throughout our service area of Iron, Beaver, and Garfield counties.

name: Iron County Care and Share
description:
ICCS is a non-profit agency. Our mission is to provide our neighbors with basic necessities of food, shelter and clothing. In order to accomplish this, ICCS provides resources for the economically disadvantaged by committing to:

- Provide temporary housing to the needy with emphasis on transients.

- Distribute donated food and government commodities to those in need.
- Provide accessibility to showers, clothing and hygiene items for the needy.
- Prepare daily hot meals and sack lunches to feed those in need.
- Provide emergency assistance to the needy in extenuating circumstances.
- Offer transitional housing.
- Cooperate with other charitable organizations, agencies, and groups to offer those in need the services that ICCS does not provide.
- Educate and inform the community about poverty issues

The food donated to (and distributed through) ICCS comes from a variety of sources, including state and local food manufacturers, distributors and retailers. Community, corporate and/or individual food drives contribute an essential mix of products for our agencies.

name: Youth Futures St. George
description:
Services are available to all youth ages 12-18.
Safe Shelter:
Doors are open 24 hours/day for youth needing safe shelter.

Drop-In Services:
Daytime services, or "drop-in" hours are 6:30am-8pm when youth may access all of the resources provided at the shelter, including food, clothing, hygiene and school supplies, and programming. Meals are served and available for all youth at 6:30 am, 12 pm, and 5pm.

name: The Road Home - Midvale Family Resource Center
organization: The Road Home - Midvale Family Resource Center
description:
Â Serving families with children. The Midvale Family Center is open year-round.
The Road Home operates our community's low-barrier shelters, meaning there are no requirements to connect to no-cost services including a bed, showers, clothing, blankets, diapers, personal toiletries, etc. We do not maintain a waiting list and provide access to our Midvale Family Center 24 hours/day, 365 days/year (including holidays).We focus on making episodes of homelessness rare, brief, and nonrecurring by providing housing-focused services and support during a short-term shelter stay. Case managers assist in connecting people with public benefits, substance abuse treatment, mental health assessment and treatment, job training and development, and housing assistance. We work to identify clients who are unable to exit shelter and help clients connect to additional supports and permanent housing opportunities as applicable as well as to onsite resources, including Valley Behavioral Health, Department of Workforce Services, and the Veterans Administration.

name: The Road Home - South Salt Lake Men's Resource Center
organization: The Road Home - South Salt Lake Men's Resource Center
description:
Serving single men. The Men's Resource Center is open year-round.
The Road Home operates our community's low-barrier shelters, meaning

there are no requirements to connect to no-cost services including a
bed, showers, clothing, blankets, diapers, personal toiletries, etc.

We do not maintain a waiting list and provide access to our Salt Lake
Community Shelter 24 hours/day, 365 days/year (including holidays).

We focus on making episodes of homelessness rare, brief, and
nonrecurring by providing housing-focused services and support during a
short-term shelter stay. Case managers assist in connecting people with
public benefits, substance abuse treatment, mental health assessment and

treatment, job training and development, and housing assistance. We
work to identify clients who are unable to exit shelter and help clients
connect to additional supports and permanent housing opportunities as
applicable as well as to onsite resources, including Valley Behavioral

name: Rescue Mission of Salt Lake - Rescue Haven
organization: Rescue Mission of Salt Lake - Rescue Haven

name: The Road Home - Palmer Court
description:
Provides affordable permanent housing for formerly homeless individuals and families. The Road Home's Palmer Court is a permanent supportive housing development with 201 units for chronically homeless single men, women and families with children.

Palmer Court is Salt Lake's newest and largest supportive housing development with 201 units for chronically homeless single men, women and families with children. This renovated hotel includes studio, 1 & 2 bedroom apartments which provide permanent housing for those who have turned to the sheltering system as a long-term housing option. Palmer Court amenities include air conditioning, secured parking, on-site laundry, exercise rooms, a computer lab, library and game room, lounge areas, and a courtyard with a playground and basketball court.

name: Family Promise of Salt Lake
description: Family Promise Salt Lake is an organization that helps families experiencing homelessness. It networks with local churches to provide shelter at night and on the weekends. There is also a Day Center that is open to families in our program during the day, so that 24 hours a day there is somewhere safe for them to be.

name: Rescue Mission of Salt Lake
description: The Rescue Mission of Salt Lake is a faith-based emergency shelter and recovery center. We offer three meals a day, free clothing, showers, laundry facilities, day shelter during inclement weather and a place to sleep every night of the week for men and women. We also run the year-long New Life recovery program, designed to get people off the streets and into housing, employment and sobriety. Services for women and children are at 1165 South State Street, phone: 801-521-5925

name: Ogden Rescue Mission
description:
Services:
Meals prepared and served to the poor and needy men, women, and children who come to the doors seeking help.
Evening nondenominational chapel services.
Residential rehabilitation program for those with addictive behaviors.
Free medical and dental care for shelter and local residents staffed by volunteer health professionals.

The Mission Thrift Store on Wall Avenue, which helps local needy families and provides jobs for the residents in the rehabilitation program.

name: Lantern House Shelter
description:
Lantern House exists to aid the poor, needy and homeless by providing them food, shelter, and critical emergency services. We provide a hand up rather than a hand out. Our goal is to transition residents from shelter to housing; encouraging their sense of independence, self-sufficiency and self-confidence. We are committed to carry out this mission while treating those who come to us with compassion, dignity, and respect.

Shelter
Accommodations for men, women, and families.
Â Â Â  Check-In times for residents is 6:00pm - 9:00pm
Â Â Â  Nightly Check-In time 10:00pm
Â Â Â  Pets are also welcome


Housing Placement
Case management services are available to all who choose to stay.

Soup Kitchen
Community breakfast and lunch is provided every day from 7:00am - 8:00am and 12:00pm - 1:00pm. Anyone is welcome to join! Dinner served nightly for Lantern House Residents.

Other
Basic essential services provided to anyone in need, hygiene kits, clothing, diapers etc. Assists people in obtaining birth certificates, ID's, bus tokens, health care, etc.

name: Peace House
description:
Peace House is a non-profit organization that provides an emergency shelter for individuals and families that are fleeing sexual assault and/or domestic violence. Peace House offers a confidential and safe environment with caring and knowledgeable staff, available 24 hours a day, that provides much needed support to these victims. All services provided are free of charge.
Additionally, while staying at the shelter, individuals will meet with a caseworker, will develop safety plans, look for jobs, work on action plans so that they can become self-sufficient, find resources so that they can get financial support and permanent housing and much more.
Shelter Services:
Personal advocacyCourt advocacyCase managementIndividualized safety planningOnsite clinical servicesDomestic violence support groupsLife skills classesImmediate needs assistance24 HOUR HELPLINE:Please contact (800) 647-9161

name: Provo Homeless Shelter - Food and Care Coalition
organization: Provo Homeless Shelter - Food and Care Coalition
description:
Now provides Transitional Housing. Visit the website provided or call the phone number provided for details.


Serving the homeless community of Utah County by providing much needed resources for food, showers, laundry, hygiene, and other basic necessities.

name: Switchpoint
description:
Intake 24/7 Case Management by Mon-Fri 9-5 or by appointment.
Beyond an emergency shelter, Switchpoint Community Resource Center

offers individualized case management to connect those experiencing
homelessness and poverty to the resources they need to move to
self-reliance.
Services Mondays through Fridays 9am to 4pm.
Dinner served at 6pm.

Pantry Hours

Monday: Clients with LAST name A-F (11 a.m. - 5 p.m.)
Tuesday: Clients with LAST name G-L (11 a.m. - 5 p.m.)
Wednesday: Clients with LAST name M-R (11 a.m. - 5 p.m.)
Thursday: Clients with LAST name S-Z (11 a.m. - 5 p.m.)
Friday: Seniors ages 62+ ONLY (11 a.m. - 5 p.m.)



Services We Offer
Clean, safe emergency living quarters
Showers
On-site laundry facility
Nutritious meals served daily
On-site computers for obtaining GED, job searching, computer skills and resume building.
On-site case management for every client
Assistance obtaining lost or stolen identification
Access to employment searching programs
Transportation vouchers
Assistance with applications and eligibility processes for Food Stamps, Medicaid, etc.
Assistance with obtaining affordable housing
Food assistance through on-site food pantry
